keyTakeAways: Mark Zuckerberg, founder of Facebook and CEO of Meta Platforms, is ordered to testify in a landmark trial over the impact of social media on young people.
Evan Spiegel, CEO of Snap, and Adam Mosseri, head of Instagram (a Meta-owned platform), are also required to testify, highlighting the broad scope of executive involvement.

The trial, consolidated in 2022, involves hundreds of claims from parents and school districts alleging that social media companies failed to implement adequate parental controls and safety features, and that 'likes' and notifications keep youth engaged and addicted.

The companies argue that federal law from the 1990s shields them from liability for user-generated content, but the judge ruled that they are still liable for negligence and personal injury due to design choices that may have harmed young users.
The judge emphasized that CEO testimony is crucial to evaluate claims of negligence, as executives possess firsthand knowledge of the harms and decisions related to product design.
Legal representatives argue that the companies chose not to modify features due to fears of business impact, suggesting a conflict between commercial interests and user safety.
The case is part of a larger wave of litigation involving Meta, Snap, TikTok, and YouTube, all facing scrutiny over mental health impacts on youth.
Zuckerberg previously stated there is no causal link between social media use and worsening mental health, but the trial challenges that position.
Instagram introduced teen accounts with content screening and parental controls in response to public and legal pressure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a landmark legal case brought by parents and school districts in Los Angeles County, social media giants Meta, Snap, TikTok, and YouTube are being sued over alleged harms to young users' mental health due to addictive design features like notifications and likes. The companies argue they are shielded by 1990s federal law, but Judge Carolyn Kuhl ruled that they remain liable for negligence in product design. The court has ordered CEO-level testimony from Mark Zuckerberg, Evan Spiegel, and Adam Mosseri, emphasizing that executives’ firsthand knowledge is essential to assessing whether the companies failed to act on known risks. This trial is among the first to directly confront claims that social media platforms knowingly designed addictive experiences, leading to long-term mental health consequences for youth. The case reflects growing public and legal scrutiny on how social media companies manage user safety and parental controls.
title: Zuckerberg to testify in landmark social media trial
